newsitem.title: USA: US West Coast crudes rise with broader market gain.
newsitem.headline: US West Coast crudes rise with broader market gain.

text.p: U.S. West Coast light crude prices jumped Monday with broader market rallies while local spot trade for Alaskan crude remained idle, traders said.

Crude oil for September delivery rose 47 cents a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange (NYMEX) to $20.75 after production of Colombian Cano Limon crude was shut-in due to rebel pipeline bombings.
In local trade, no barrels of Alaska North Slope (ANS) traded, but foreign grades began to trickle in for September, traders said.

A major refiner, headquartered in New York, bought a cargo of Maya (Mexico) Monday, traders said, but did not specify its volume or destination. The cargo is the second purchased by the refinery in the last two months.
About five cargoes of the heavy, sour crude are arriving into West Coast refineries this month and will be tested for compatibility in their processing units.
Another large West Coast refiner also bought a cargo of South Blend crude at a price of $3.10 under September West Texas Intermediate/Cushing (WTI), traders said.
Traders also said a large independent late last week bought a partial cargo of ANS at the going market spot price.
Kern River heavy grade rose after Chevron Corp raised its postings late Monday.
